content:
Excellent idea! Creating separate folders for each trip will help you keep your photos organized and make it easier to find specific memories. It's also a good way to reflect on the different experiences and emotions associated with each trip.

So, your updated folder structure could look like this:

* Napa Valley
	+ Day 1
		- Winery 1
		- Lunch at [restaurant name]
		- Scenic views
	+ Day 2
		- Winery 2
		- Wine tasting at [winery name]
		- Dinner at [restaurant name]
	+ Wineries
		- [Winery 1 name]
		- [Winery 2 name]
		- [Winery 3 name]

* Hawaii
	+ Island of Oahu
		- Waikiki Beach
		- Pearl Harbor
		- Hanauma Bay Snorkeling
	+ Island of Maui
		- Road to Hana
		- Haleakala National Park
		- Lahaina Town
	+ Island of Kauai
		- Na Pali Coast
		- Wailua River State Park
		- Poipu Beach

* Yosemite
	+ Day 1
		- Yosemite Valley
		- Half Dome
		- Waterfalls
	+ Day 2
		- Glacier Point
		- Tuolumne Meadows
		- Hiking to [trail name]

* San Francisco
	+ Solo Trip (2022)
		- Landmarks
			- Golden Gate Bridge
			- Alcatraz Island
			- Lombard Street
		- Neighborhoods
			- Fisherman's Wharf
			- Haight-Ashbury
			- Chinatown
	+ Family Trip (2020)
		- Landmarks
			- Pier 39
			- Golden Gate Park
			- Coit Tower
		- Neighborhoods
			- North Beach
			- Union Square
			- The Mission

* Disney World
	+ Family Trip (2020)
		- Magic Kingdom
			- Cinderella's Castle
			- Space Mountain
			- Character Meet-and-Greets
		- Epcot
			- World Showcase
			- Soarin'
			- Illuminations
		- Hollywood Studios
			- Star Wars: Galaxy's Edge
			- Tower of Terror
			- Fantasmic!

This way, you can easily access and relive the memories of each trip, and even compare the differences between your solo and family trips to San Francisco.

Remember to also consider adding captions or descriptions to your photos, so you can include more context and stories behind each image.
